subject: Re: [junit] How to Test Private Methods Inside a Class
msgSnippet: In addition to the two options below I would add what I think Stephen Smith was suggesting: 3. Look for an abstraction and extract the private methods you want
messageBody:
In addition to the two options below I would add what I think Stephen
Smith was suggesting:

3. Look for an abstraction and extract the private methods you want to
test into a separate, testable class. Inspired By Cederics example and
refering to the Java-API, let's say that you have the private method
int compare(Object left, Object right) that compares two objects. That
can be extracted to a comparator with that method as a public
interface (yes I completely stile the exam√∂ple from the Java API
what's wong with that? :)). An implementation of that interface could
be instantiated and used in the your tested class AND it could and
should be tested in isolation outside of that class.

I would look for abstractions first, I have yet to find a situation
where I need to test private methods with reflection and I very
seldomly, if ever need to open up the API in a way that feels
"unnatural". When I do that a better solution usually presents itself
later (so opening up can be a way to keep your flow).

I think SRP is one of the most important principles when TDD:ing:
http://www.objectmentor.com/resources/articles/srp

If something is hard to test the reason is often that SRP has been violated.

Just my two cents for what they are worth.
/J


> Back to the original question. You have two options:
>
> - You absolutely want to keep that method private, and in this case,
> you should probably invoke it via reflection (see setAccessible(true)).
>
> - You can relax the visibility of this method, in which case I suggest
> making it package protected and then put your test in the same package (it
> can still be in a separate source folder).
>
> I recommend the latter approach...
>
